bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 17, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg thanks Hench for the letter, from Agramonte's daughter, in which she criticized the preliminary sketches of Cornwell's painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 17, 1941
div1.opener:
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
March 17th, 1941
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Supplementary to the letter I wrote you yesterday: since
receiving your letter of the 14th this morning, I find that
you answered the question concerning your Palm Beach address.

Mr. Cornwell has been away for almost ten days, as have I,
but I am expecting him to be in his studio this morning and
will go over and sort from the material which you have loaned
us, all that which has either been copied or is not absolutely
necessary for his work during the next week. As I said in
my letter yesterday, the black and white photographs of the
sketches will reach you in Florida.

To me the letter from Miss Agramonte is one of the most revealing
that I have read. I am writing her today as per copy attached.
Had we met her in Cuba I think the painting would have been well
on its way by now. She is frank, and as you say somewhat bitter
but she is obviously intelligent and her criticisms are specific
and well taken. We certainly appreciate the fact that you
sent us a copy of her letter.

I am returning the Rochester, Minnesota article and the carica-
ture booklet with this letter, but the copies of other correspond-
ence I mentioned yesterday will not be ready until tomorrow.
They should reach you before you leave.
